results.title: In my blood
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jack Bell and ACMI
results.brief_description: Serving in Libya , Jack was captured and became a POW. Almost dying from injures , he would spend over 3 months in prisoner camps in Europe. Today he still remember his mates who didn’t make it and the doctor who who saved his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jack Bell and ACMI

results.title: The Effects of war never change
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jeff Freeman and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jeff only served 2 years in the army in South Vietnam. It was extremely hard to return to normal life and keep an office job after one year in the jungle. The reaction to Vietnam veterans in Australia only made it harder for him to adjust back into a normal life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jeff Freeman and ACMI

results.title: An Airman at sea
results.brief_description: As Keith flew from Townsville to Milne Bay in Papua New Guinea, he wondered if he would ever see the shores of Australia again. Suffering from dengue fever, Keith battled illness the whole time. He made it back when the war ended and would go on to serve in the RAFF for 20 years.
results.description: As Keith flew from Townsville to Milne Bay in Papua New Guinea, he wondered if he would ever see the shores of Australia again. Suffering from dengue fever, Keith battled illness the whole time. He made it back when the war ended and would go on to serve in the RAFF for 20 years.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [St Arnaud Veterans]
results.brief_description: While many didn’t see active service, these ten veterans from St Anaud count their time in the army as the most important part of their lives. Proud of their service, they tell of exciting adventures, adjusting to big changes and the friends they made along the way.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [St Arnaud Veterans]

results.title: The Wind beneath their wings
results.creator_credit: Gwen Hancock, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a shy country girl, Gwen joined the Air Force when she was 18 years old and was posted at several locations around Victoria. Becoming a dressmaker after she was discharged from the army, Gwen married and lived life on a farm where she cultivated brown sheep, Shetland ponies and goats.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwen Hancock, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: We kept them flying
results.creator_credit: Maude Coates, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: On the way home from enrolling in the Women’s Australian Auxiliary Air Force (WAAAF) in 1941, Maude Coates learnt that the Japanese forces had just bombed Darwin. For almost 4 years, Coates worked hard and built a great sense of companionship with the other women she lived and worked with. Serving time in the Women’s Forces out of duty, Maude feels proud to have served her country and been part of history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maude Coates, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Survivor
results.creator_credit: Oz Phillips, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: At 18, Oswald enlisted in the Army through the Scotch College Cadet Force. He served in Darwin for two and a half years, surviving 76 raids, before training for inventory and being sent to Borneo to engage the Japanese. He can only recall the experience with “fear, fright and exhilaration”. Declared unfit for military service, he took some time to feel better again before marrying in 1950.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oz Phillips, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

He can only recall the experience with “fear, fright and exhilaration”. Declared unfit for military service, he took some time to feel better again before marrying in 1950.

He can only recall the experience with “fear, fright and exhilaration”. Declared unfit for military service, he took some time to feel better again before marrying in 1950.

results.title: The St Arnaud boys
results.creator_credit: Norm Michael, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Norm started his life in the Army with six other local boys from his local area. He really enjoyed the mateship and sense of community he shared with them, and reminisces on the good times they had over the years. The mateship still lives on today when Norm catches up with them back in their home town, St Arnaud.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norm Michael, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: On the road again
results.creator_credit: Bill Medlyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 1942, Bill joined the army, taking his brothers place who returned home to work on the farm. Bill worked in many capacities as a driver and instructor. Having a severe driving accident on a mission, Bill landed in hospital for three months with a fractured spine. Making a good recovery, he was able to return to service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Medlyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Life on the farm
results.creator_credit: Oz Sanderson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Oz Sanderson grew up on his farm with his two brothers during the Great Depression. His dad signed a consent form for him to join the army. While Oz was determined to serve as a pilot, the farm was always in his heart and he was more than happy to return to it after the war ended.
